{{see also|Cricket in World War I}} {{Use British English|date=March 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} {{Infobox cricket tournament | administrator = | cricket format = | tournament format = | champions = | count = | participants = | matches = | most runs = | most wickets = | previous_year = 1914 | previous_tournament = 1914 English cricket season | next_year = 1919 | next_tournament = 1919 English cricket season }}
The '''1915 to 1918 English cricket seasons''' were all but wiped out by the [[First World War]].
The [[1914 English cricket season]] ended prematurely after the outbreak of the war and it was not until the [[1919 English cricket season|1919 season]] that normal first-class fixtures could resume.
However, cricket did not fade away during the war: it was played in schools and universities, on the streets and by the soldiers and airmen on active service, whilst ''[[Wisden Cricketers' Almanack|John Wisden’s Cricketers’ Almanac]]'' continued to publish every spring.
==1915== The 1915 [[County Championship]] was not officially abandoned until January. [[Surrey CCC]], despite [[The Oval]] having been commandeered by the military, issued a statement that spring which “hoped that some matches may be played in July and August”. It was a [[forlorn hope]].
==1916== Club cricket in the south of England went into serious decline and many clubs closed down indefinitely. In the north, efforts were made to keep the leagues alive and the Bradford League did very well indeed, with large crowds reported, especially after the Saltaire club signed the great bowler [[Sydney Barnes]].
==1917== [[Plum Warner]], at home on sick leave, had an idea to stage services charity matches at [[Lord's]]. These would involve Dominions teams against English servicemen. [[Colin Blythe]] played in one shortly before he was killed.
The number of games increased as cricket began to be viewed as a morale booster. Birley records that "as many as 119 services and schools games were played at Canterbury in 1917”.
A Yorkshire County XII played two-day matches against teams representing the Bradford League and the Yorkshire Council league.
When the 1918 ''Wisden'' was published, it honoured the ''School Bowlers of the Year'' - [[Harry Calder]], [[John Firth (cricketer)|John Firth]], [[Clement Gibson]], [[Gerard Rotherham]] and [[Greville Stevens]].
==1918== The charity and holiday games continued in 1918. This was a second successive warm summer<ref>[http://climexp.knmi.nl//data/tstcet.txt Hadley Centre Central England Temperature]</ref> and games were again well attended, especially league games with former county or Test professionals in action.
The 1919 ''Wisden'' honoured ''Five Public School Cricketers of the Year'' - [[Percy Adams (cricketer)|Percy Adams]], [[Percy Chapman]], [[Adrian Gore (cricketer)|Adrian Gore]], [[Lionel Hedges]] and [[Norman Partridge (cricketer)|Norman Partridge]]. Chapman went on to captain England.

[[Jackie Stewart]] }} The '''1971 Miller High Life 500''' was a [[NASCAR]] [[Monster Energy NASCAR Cup Series|Winston Cup Series]] (now Monster Energy NASCAR Cup Series) event that took place at [[Ontario Motor Speedway]] in [[Ontario, California]].{{cite web | url = http://www.racing-reference.info/race?id=1971-05&series=W| title = 1971 Miller High Life 500 information | publisher = Racing Reference | date = | accessdate = 2009-10-21}} The race car drivers still had to commute to the races using the same stock cars that competed in a typical weekend's race through a policy of [[homologation (motorsport)|homologation]] (and under their own power). This policy was in effect until roughly 1975. By 1980, NASCAR had completely stopped tracking the year model of all the vehicles and most teams did not take stock cars to the track under their own power any more. ==Summary== Two hundred laps were taken on a paved [[oval track racing|oval track]] spanning {{convert|2.500|mi|km}}. The total time of the race was three hours, forty-three minutes, and thirty-six seconds. This would be the first event to ever take place at Ontario Speedway. The day of the race was February 28, 1971. Average speed was {{convert|134.168|mi/h}} and the pole position speed was {{convert|151.711|mi/h}}. There were five cautions for 21 laps and the margin of victory was 8½ seconds. With an attendance of nearly seventy-nine thousand people, the race was well attended even by modern standards.{{cite web | url = http://fantasyracingcheatsheet.com/nascar/races/results/1971/ontario-motor-speedway/miller-high-life-500/1216| title = 1971 Miller High Life 500 information (third reference) | publisher = Fantasy Racing Cheat Sheet | date = | accessdate = 2011-05-06}} Eleven notable crew chiefs were recorded as being a part of this event; including [[Paul Goldsmith]], [[Richard Elder]], [[Harry Hyde]], [[Dale Inman]], Lee Gordon and [[Paul Burchard]].{{cite web | url = http://www.racing-reference.info/entrylist/1971-05/W/C| title = 1971 Miller High Life 500 crew chief information | publisher = Racing Reference | date = | accessdate = 2017-06-17}} In the 51-man entire racing grid, there were 50 [[United States|American]]s and only one [[Mexico|Mexican]] (by the name of [[Pedro Rodríguez (racing driver)|Pedro Rodríguez]] who finished in 47th due to an electrical fault). It was the 1000th race ever to be accomplished in NASCAR history. Rodríguez would retire from the NASCAR Winston Cup Series after his race here. [[Dean Dalton]] would finish in last place due to being black flagged and disqualified on lap 2. The only car in the same league with Foyt was Freddie Lorenzen until Lorenzen's engine blew and he crashed on the front straight with a fire. At the end, Petty had a chance to win, but he missed his pit under the green flag and had to come back in and finished third. Foyt won the first two Ontario races. The total winnings of the race were considered to be $180,200 (${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|180200|1971|r=2}}}} when adjusted for inflation) - making it the biggest non-[[Daytona 500|Daytona]] purse during that era. Manufacturers involved in the event included [[Chevrolet]], [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]], [[Dodge]], [[Mercury (automobile)|Mercury]], and [[Plymouth (automobile)|Plymouth]]. Other notable drivers included [[Elmo Langley]], [[Fred Lorenzen]], and [[Ron Hornaday, Sr.]] (whose [[Ron Hornaday, Jr.|son]] is a four-time [[Camping World Truck Series|Craftsman Truck Series]] champion). [[Marty Kinerk]] would also retire after this race along with Jim McElreath, Pedro Rodríguez and Johnny Steele.[http://www.race-database.com/results/results.php?year=1971&race=5&series_id=2 Drivers who retired after this race] at Race Database ===Qualifying=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! On February 1, 2005, the [[Emergency Alert System]] was activated in portions of [[Connecticut]] calling for the immediate evacuation of the entire state. The activation was in error. Later studies showed that residents did not evacuate, and that the most common response was to 'change the channel' or seek other confirmation.
==Background== The Emergency Alert System (EAS) is a public warning system in the [[United States]] that allows designated government authorities to suspend and preempt terrestrial radio and television broadcasts when needed to issue urgent public safety alerts. The highest priority alert that can be issued is an Emergency Action Notification (EAN), sometimes called a "presidential alert". An EAN sets into motion a series of events that causes all of the United States' television and radio stations to become networked together to simulcast the [[President of the United States]], or another federal official. An Emergency Action Notification has never been used for an actual event. However, local and state-level activations of the EAS routinely occur for emergencies such as [[tornado]]es, [[9-1-1|911]] system outages, and other, localized, exigent events.<ref>{{cite web|title=Emergency Alert System (EAS) Plan for Connecticut |url=http://www.ctba.org/docs/CT_EAS_State_Plan_Final_Feb_2017.pdf|website=CTBA|publisher=Connecticut Broadcasters Association|accessdate=February 15, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.fcc.gov/document/september-28-2016-nationwide-eas-test|title=September 28, 2016 Nationwide EAS Test|date=2017-04-21|work=Federal Communications Commission|access-date=2018-01-14|language=en}}</ref>
==Incident== At 2:10 p.m. on Tuesday, February 1, 2005, a state-level activation of the EAS occurred in Connecticut.<ref name="courant"/> A scheduled, unannounced test of the system had been planned for that day. However, the system instead informed television and radio stations that an evacuation of the state was underway. Both the Connecticut Office of Emergency Management and Governor [[Jodi Rell]] issued statements shortly after the broadcast confirming the activation had been in error and there was no evacuation underway, though clarifications were not issued until more than an hour after the transmission.<ref name="nbc"/>
Officials initially blamed [[hacker]]s for the misactivation, though an employee of the state's Office of Emergency Management later said they had accidentally registered the incorrect code prior to what should have been an EAS test, prompting the broadcast of the evacuation notification instead of the test message.<ref name="courant">{{cite news|last1=Pazinokas|first1=Mark|title=Connecticut Evacuation: False Alarm|url=http://articles.courant.com/2005-02-02/news/0502020861_1_evacuation-order-false-alarm-emergency-alert-system|accessdate=February 15, 2017|work=[[Hartford Courant]]|date=February 2, 2005}}</ref>
According to media reports, the message broadcast began, "civil authorities have issued an immediate evacuation order for all of Connecticut, beginning at 2:10 p.m. and ending at 3:10 p.m".<ref>{{cite news|title=False alarm in Connecticut evacuation order|url=http://www.upi.com/False-alarm-in-Connecticut-evacuation-order/19241107352381/|accessdate=February 15, 2017|work=[[UPI]]|date=February 2, 2005}}</ref>
==Reaction== Despite the critical nature of the message, officials from the [[Connecticut State Police]] reported they received no calls from the public inquiring as to its authenticity or the circumstances that would require the evacuation of Connecticut.<ref name="nbc">{{cite news|title=Evacuate! Evacuate! Oh ... nevermind|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/6895811/ns/us_news-weird_news/t/evacuate-evacuate-oh-never-mind/#.WKQTUW8rKM8|accessdate=February 15, 2017|work=[[NBC News]]|date=February 1, 2005}}</ref> Though some local police reportedly received calls from members of the public, the message "failed to set off a noticeable exodus into Massachusetts, Rhode Island or New York".<ref name="courant"/>
A study conducted after the activation discovered that 11 percent of the state's residents had received the warning while it was being broadcast. Of those persons, 63 percent reported they were "a little or not at all concerned" when receiving it. The most common reaction reported by residents was to seek confirmation of the emergency by changing channels; other common reactions were looking outside or consulting neighbors, and only one percent of persons surveyed who heard the broadcast actually attempted to flee Connecticut.<ref name="study">{{cite web|title=Public Reaction to the Erroneous Statewide Broadcast of February 1st, 2005 |url=https://www2.gwu.edu/~icdrm/publications/CT%20Emergency%20Broadcast%20Final%20Report.pdf|website=[[George Washington University]]|publisher=Center for Survey Research and Analysis|accessdate=February 15, 2017}}</ref>
The most common reasons given by people for not following the evacuation orders were because no specific threat was described in the broadcast, because no specific area was mentioned other than "the entire state of Connecticut", and because there was no observable activity indicative of an emergency.<ref name="study"/>

{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2012}} [[File:ATHF LED in Cambridge.jpg|thumb|right|An LED display resembling the cartoon character [[Ignignokt]] from ''[[Aqua Teen Hunger Force]]'' giving [[the finger]] as seen in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]]. Identical devices throughout the community were removed by the [[Boston Police Department]] and the [[Boston Fire Department]] on January 31, 2007.|260px]] The '''2007 Boston Mooninite panic''' occurred on Wednesday, January 31, 2007, after the [[Boston Police Department]] and the [[Boston Fire Department]] mistakenly identified battery-powered [[LED]] placards depicting [[the Mooninites]], characters from the [[Adult Swim]] animated television series ''[[Aqua Teen Hunger Force]]'', as [[improvised explosive devices]].{{cite news|author=Byron, Katy |author2=Kelley, Rob |title=Cartoon Network boss quits over bomb scare |url=http://money.cnn.com/2007/02/09/news/newsmakers/cartoon_network/ |work=CNNMoney.com |date=February 9, 2007 |accessdate=December 13, 2007 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5msUTGSR1?url=http://money.cnn.com/2007/02/09/news/newsmakers/cartoon_network/ |archivedate=January 18, 2010 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }}{{cite news|author=Smalley, Suzanne |author2=Mishra, Raja |title=Froth, fear, and fury |url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2007/02/01/froth_fear_and_fury/?page=full |work=The Boston Globe |publisher=The New York Times Company |date=February 1, 2007 |accessdate=February 2, 2007 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5whIQAJx7?url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2007/02/01/froth_fear_and_fury/?page=full |archivedate=February 22, 2011 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} Placed throughout [[Boston, Massachusetts]], and the surrounding cities of [[Cambridge, Massachusetts|Cambridge]] and [[Somerville, Massachusetts|Somerville]], these devices were part of a [[guerrilla marketing]] [[advertising campaign]] for ''[[Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters]]'', a film based on ''Aqua Teen Hunger Force''. The incident led to controversy and criticism from a number of media sources, including ''[[The Boston Globe]]'', ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', [[Fox News]], ''[[The San Francisco Chronicle]]'', ''[[The New York Times]]'', [[CNN]] and ''[[The Boston Herald]]'', some of which ridiculed the city's response to the devices as disproportionate and indicative of a [[generation gap]] between city officials and the younger residents of Boston, at whom the ads were targeted. Several sources noted that the hundreds of officers in the Boston police department or city emergency planning office on scene were unable to identify the figure depicted for several hours until a younger staffer at Mayor [[Thomas Menino]]'s office saw the media coverage and recognized the figures as cartoon characters from the TV show. After the devices were removed, the Boston Police Department stated in their defense that the ad devices shared "some characteristics with improvised explosive devices," which they said included an "identifiable power source, a [[Printed circuit board|circuit board]] with exposed wiring, and electrical tape." Investigators were not mollified by the discovery that the devices were not explosive in nature, stating they still intended to determine "if this event was a [[hoax]] or something else entirely." Although city [[prosecutors]] eventually concluded there was no [[mens rea|ill intent]] involved in the placing of the ads, the city continues to refer to the event as a "bomb hoax" (implying intent) rather than a "bomb scare."{{cite news |first=John R.|last=Ellement |first2=Andrew|last2=Ryan | title=Bomb squad removes suspicious object that closed I-93 north | date= January 31, 2007 |url=http://www.google.com/search?q=cache:FeooQCvkYXkJ:www.boston.com/news/globe/city_region/breaking_news/2007/01/bomb_squad_remo.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20121203164442/http://www.google.com/search?q=cache:FeooQCvkYXkJ:www.boston.com/news/globe/city_region/breaking_news/2007/01/bomb_squad_remo.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=December 3, 2012 | work =Posted by the Boston Globe City & Region Desk | accessdate =February 6, 2007 }}{{cite news | title='Suspicious' Package Not Bomb, Police Say WCVB-TV | date= January 31, 2007 | publisher=wyff4.com | url =http://google.com/search?q=cache:PLqt7oH-XqoJ:www.wyff4.com/news/10888268/detail.html | work =WCVB-TV | accessdate =February 6, 2007 }}{{dead link|date=September 2016}}{{cite news|agency=Associated Press |title=Turner, 2nd firm to pay $2 million over scare |date=February 5, 2007 |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/16990202/ |publisher=MSNBC |accessdate=December 19, 2007 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5whIRWJV7?url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/16990202/ |archivedate=February 22, 2011 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} Reflecting back on the incident years later, various academics and media sources have characterized the reaction to the marketing campaign as a form of [[social panic]]. Author Gregory Bergman wrote in his 2008 book ''BizzWords'' that the devices were basically a self-made form of the children's toy [[Lite-Brite]]. [[Computer security]] expert [[Bruce Schneier]] wrote in his 2009 book ''Schneier on Security'' that Boston officials were "ridiculed" for their overreaction to the incident. In his 2009 book ''Secret Agents'', historian and communication professor Jeremy Packer discussed a phenomenon in culture called the "panic discourse" and described the incident as a "spectacular instance of this panic". In a 2012 article ''[[The Boston Phoenix]]'' called the incident the "Great Mooninite Panic of 2007". A 2013 publication by [[WGBH Educational Foundation|WGBH]] News wrote that the majority of Boston youth thought that the arrests of two men who placed devices, Peter "Zebbler" Berdovsky and Sean Stevens, were not warranted. == Planning == In November 2006, [[Boston]] area artist [[Zebbler]] (aka Peter Berdovsky) met John{{who|date=April 2016}} (aka VJ Aiwaz) in [[New York City]]. John worked for a marketing organization named [[Interference, Inc.]], and asked Berdovsky if he would be interested in working on a promotional project. Berdovsky agreed and enlisted the help of Sean Stevens for the project. Interference shipped Berdovsky 40 electronic signs. Adrienne Yee of Interference e-mailed him a list of suggested locations and a list of things not to do. According to police, the suggested locations for the devices included "train stations, overpasses, hip/trendy areas and high traffic/high visibility areas." The signs were to be put up discreetly overnight. They were to be paid $300 each for their assistance. Berdovsky, Stevens, and Dana Seaver put up 20 magnetic lights in the middle of January. They dubbed the activity "Boston Mission 1." While Stevens and Berdovsky put up the lights, Seaver recorded the activity on video and sent a copy to Interference. On the night of January 29, 2007, in what was called "Boston Mission 2," 18 more magnetic lights were put in place. This included one under [[Interstate 93]] at [[Sullivan Square (Boston)|Sullivan Square]] in [[Charlestown, Boston|Charlestown]].{{cite news|author=Levenson, Michael |author2=Mishra, Raja |title=Turner Broadcasting accepts blame, promises restitution |url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/articles/2007/02/02/turner_broadcasting_accepts_blame_promises_restitution/?page=full |work=The Boston Globe |publisher=The New York Times Company |date=February 2, 2007 |accessdate=February 2, 2007 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5whIS3keF?url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/articles/2007/02/02/turner_broadcasting_accepts_blame_promises_restitution/?page=full |archivedate=February 22, 2011 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }}{{cite news|author=Levenson, Michael |author2=Mishra, Raja |author3=Cramer, Maria |title=Turner Broadcasting accepts full responsibility for scare |url=http://www.boston.com/news/globe/city_region/breaking_news/2007/02/guerrilla_ad_ag.html |work=The Boston Globe |publisher=The New York Times Company |date=February 1, 2007 |accessdate=February 1, 2007 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5whISJNcT?url=http://www.boston.com/news/globe/city_region/breaking_news/2007/02/guerrilla_ad_ag.html |archivedate=February 22, 2011 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} === Devices === [[File:Mooninite5.jpg|thumb|The devices were not lit until the afternoon.]] The devices closely resembled the Night Writer promoted by the [[Graffiti Research Lab]] in early 2006.[http://graffitiresearchlab.com/?page_id=19 Night Writer] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/5whITNbVM?url=http://graffitiresearchlab.com/?page_id=19 |date=February 22, 2011 }} The devices were promotional electronic placards for the forthcoming ''[[Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters]]''. Each device, measuring about 1 by 1.5 feet, consisted of a [[printed circuit board]] (PCB) with black [[soldermask]], [[light-emitting diode]]s, and other electronic components soldered to it, including numerous [[resistor]]s, a few [[capacitor]]s, and at least one [[integrated circuit]] package. At the bottom was a pack of four [[Publix]] brand [[List of battery sizes|D-cell batteries]], with magnets attached to the back so the devices could be easily mounted on any [[Ferromagnetism|ferromagnetic]] surface. The batteries were originally covered in black tape to blend in with the black PCB. The [[LED lights]] were arranged to represent the [[The Mooninites|Mooninite]] characters displaying [[the middle finger]].{{cite news| date=January 31, 2007|title=Arrest Made In Boston's Hoax Device Incident|publisher=CBS Corporation|url=http://cbs4boston.com/topstories/local_story_031135507.html |accessdate=January 31, 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080516101001/http://cbs4boston.com/topstories/local_story_031135507.html |archivedate=May 16, 2008 }}{{cite news|url=http://www.thebostonchannel.com/news/10890113/detail.html |author=Jamy Pombo |title=TV Network Takes Responsibility For 'Hoax Devices' |publisher=ABC |date=January 31, 2007 |accessdate=January 31, 2007 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5whITSQbC?url=http://www.thebostonchannel.com/news/10890113/detail.html |archivedate=February 22, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }} Two variants were manufactured with the LEDs arranged in [[Pixelization|pixelated]] likenesses of Ignignokt and Err, Mooninite characters from ''Aqua Teen Hunger Force''. [[Massachusetts Attorney General]] [[Martha Coakley]] said the device "had a very sinister appearance. It had a battery behind it, and wires."{{cite news | last = Lothian | first = Dan |author2=Fran Fifis|author3=Deborah Feyerick | title = Two plead not guilty to Boston hoax charges | publisher = CNN | date = February 1, 2007 | url = http://www.cnn.com/2007/US/02/01/boston.bombscare/ | accessdate =February 2, 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070203050621/http://www.cnn.com/2007/US/02/01/boston.bombscare/ |archivedate = February 3, 2007}} Others compared the displays to the [[Lite-Brite]] electric toy in appearance. == Subsequent scare == On January 31, 2007, at 8:05 a.m., a passenger spotted one of the devices on a [[stanchion]] that supports an elevated section of Interstate 93 (I-93), above [[Sullivan Square (MBTA station)|Sullivan Station]] and told a policeman with the [[Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority]] (MBTA) of its presence. At 9 a.m., the [[Boston Police Department]] bomb squad received a phone call from the MBTA requesting assistance in identifying the device.{{cite web | url = http://www.bpdnews.com/2007/02/message_from_the_police_commis_2.html | title = Message From The Police Commissioner | accessdate =February 3, 2007 | last = Davis | first = Ed | date = February 2, 2007 | work = BPDNews.com | publisher = Boston Police Department |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070203120922/http://www.bpdnews.com/2007/02/message_from_the_police_commis_2.html |archivedate = February 3, 2007}} Authorities responded with what the ''[[Boston Globe]]'' described as "[an] army of emergency vehicles" at the scene, including police cruisers, fire trucks, ambulances, and the Boston Police Department bomb squad. Also present were live TV crews, large crowd of onlookers, and helicopters circling overhead. Peter Berdovsky, who had placed the device, went to the scene and video recorded the situation. Berdovsky recognized the device with which the police were dealing, but made no attempt to inform the police at the scene. Berdovsky returned to his apartment and contacted Interference, the company who had hired him to place the lights. He was told by Interference that they would handle informing the police and that he should personally say nothing about the situation.[http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/02/06/ap/national/mainD8N4BOQG0.shtml Man in Boston Scare Videotaped Police: Defendant in Boston marketing stunt scare videotaped police response, attorney says] Feb. 6, 2007 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090315022602/http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/02/06/ap/national/mainD8N4BOQG0.shtml |date=March 15, 2009 }} During the preliminary investigation at the site, police found that the device shared "some characteristics with [[improvised explosive devices]]." These characteristics included an identifiable power source, circuit board with exposed wiring, and electrical tape. After the initial assessment, Boston police shut down the northbound side of I-93 and parts of the public transportation system. Just after 10 a.m., the bomb squad used a small explosive filled with water to destroy the device as a precaution. MBTA Transit police Lieutenant Salvatore Venturelli told the media at the scene, "This is a perfect example of our passengers taking part in [[homeland security]]." He refused to describe the object in detail because of the ongoing investigation, responding only that "It's not consistent with equipment that would be there normally." Investigators were trying to determine "if it was a hoax or something else entirely," according to Venturelli. Northbound I-93 reopened to traffic at about 10:05 a.m. By 10:21 a.m. it was determined to be "some sort of hoax device," according to a police timeline of the events. At 12:54 p.m., Boston police received a call identifying another device located at the intersection of Stuart and [[Charles Street (Boston)|Charles Street]]. At 1:11 p.m. the [[Massachusetts State Police]] requested assistance from the bomb squad with devices found under the [[Longfellow Bridge|Longfellow]] and [[Boston University Bridge|Boston University]] bridges. Both bridges were closed as a precaution, and the [[United States Coast Guard|Coast Guard]] closed the river to boat traffic.{{cite news|title=Man held after ad campaign triggers Boston bomb scare |url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/US/01/31/boston.bombscare/index.html |date=February 1, 2007 |accessdate=February 2, 2007 |publisher=CNN |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5whIUE7B8?url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/US/01/31/boston.bombscare/index.html |archivedate=February 22, 2011 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }}{{cite news |title=Security alert shuts Boston's Charles River |date=January 31, 2007 | publisher= Reuters }} At 1:26 p.m., friends of Peter Berdovsky received an e-mail from him, which alleged that five hours into the scare, an Interference Inc. executive requested Berdovsky "keep everything on the [[wiktionary:down low|dl]]." Travis Vautour, a friend of Berdovsky, stated: "We received an e-mail in the early afternoon from Peter that asked the community that he's a part of to keep any information we had on the down low and that was instructed to him by whoever his boss was."{{cite news|url=http://www.abcnews.go.com/Technology/story?id=2841646&page=1 |title=As Boston Reeled, Was Artist Asked to Keep Quiet? |last=Silverstein |first=Jonathan |publisher=ABC News |date=February 2, 2007 |accessdate=February 2, 2007 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5whIV4m7Q?url=http://www.abcnews.go.com/Technology/story?id=2841646&page=1 |archivedate=February 22, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Two hours later, Interference notified their client, [[Cartoon Network]]. Between 2 and 3 p.m., a police analyst identified the image on the devices as an ''Aqua Teen Hunger Force'' cartoon character, and police concluded the incident was a publicity stunt. [[Turner Broadcasting System]] issued a statement concerning the event at around 4:30 p.m. Portions of the Turner statement read:
We regret that they were mistakenly thought to pose any danger. The packages in question are magnetic lights that pose no danger. They are part of an outdoor marketing campaign in 10 cities in support of Adult Swim's animated television show Aqua Teen Hunger Force. They have been in place for two to three weeks in Boston, New York City, Los Angeles, Chicago, [[Atlanta]], [[Seattle]], [[Portland, Oregon|Portland]], [[Austin, Texas|Austin]], San Francisco, and [[Philadelphia]]. Parent company Turner Broadcasting is in contact with local and federal law enforcement on the exact locations of the billboards. We regret that they were mistakenly thought to pose any danger.{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/US/01/31/TBS.statement/index.html |title=Statement from Turner Broadcasting Co. |accessdate=February 2, 2007 |last=Powell |first=Shirley |date=January 31, 2007 |work=CNN |publisher=TBS Corporate Communications |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5whIVBEkS?url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/US/01/31/TBS.statement/index.html |archivedate=February 22, 2011 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }}
Some devices had been up for two weeks in the cities listed before the Boston incident occurred, although no permits were ever secured for the devices' installation. The marketing company responsible for the campaign, Interference, Inc., made no comment on the situation and their website was down (restored as of February 3, 2007).{{cite web|title=Movie News – "Hunger Force" Ad Campaign Causes Boston Bomb Scare |url=http://www.filmfodder.com/mt-weblog/archives/003544.shtml |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5whIVdlBb?url=http://www.filmfodder.com/mt-weblog/archives/003544.shtml |archivedate=February 22, 2011 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} Berdovsky and Stevens, the individuals hired by Interference to install the signs, were arrested by Boston police during the evening of January 31, and charged with violating Chapter 266: Section 102A½ of the [[General Laws of Massachusetts]], which states that it is illegal to display a "hoax device" with the motive to cause citizens to feel threatened, unsafe, and concerned.{{cite journal|title=Possession, transportation, use or placement of hoax devices |journal=The General Laws of Massachusetts |issue=Chapter 266: Section 102A1/2 |url=http://www.mass.gov/legis/laws/mgl/266-102a.5.htm |accessdate=February 1, 2007 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5whIWovEZ?url=http://www.mass.gov/legis/laws/mgl/266-102a.5.htm |archivedate=February 22, 2011 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} Both were held at the State Police South Boston barracks overnight and were released on $2,500 bail from the Charlestown Division of [[Boston Municipal Court]] the following morning. ===Reactions=== {{multiple image |title=[[Lite-Brite]] and a Mooninite display |total_width=500 |width1=1734|height1= 1426|image1=Hello on a Lite-Brite.jpg|caption1=A Lite-Brite (without black paper) spelling "hello"|alt1=Lite-Brite (without black paper) spelling "hello" |width2=1395|height2=1413|image2=Mooninite2.jpg|caption2=Close-up of one of the [[LED]] displays resembling [[Ignignokt]] while being lit|alt2=Close-up of one of the LED displays while being lit |footer=Lite-Brite children's toy (left) and Mooninite display (right) |caption_align=center }} ''The Boston Globe'' stated that the "marketing gambit exposes a wide generation gap," quoting one 29-year-old blogger as writing "Repeat after me, authorities. L-E-D. Not [[Improvised explosive device|I-E-D]]. Get it?"{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/articles/2007/02/01/marketing_gambit_exposes_a_wide_generation_gap/ |title=Marketing gambit exposes a wide generation gap |work=The Boston Globe |date=February 1, 2007 |accessdate=February 2, 2007 |last=Levenson |first=Michael |author2=Cramer, Maria |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5whIWsnAA?url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/articles/2007/02/01/marketing_gambit_exposes_a_wide_generation_gap/ |archivedate=February 22, 2011 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} The ''Globe''{{'}}s ''Brainiac'' blog was quick to credit bloggers such as Todd Vanderlin and Brian Stuart for being among the first to report on the ad's origin.{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/news/globe/ideas/brainiac/2007/01/attack_of_the_m.html |title=Attack of the Mooninites! |work=The Boston Globe |date=January 31, 2007 |accessdate=April 18, 2007 |last=Glenn |first=Joshua |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5whIX7iyg?url=http://www.boston.com/news/globe/ideas/brainiac/2007/01/attack_of_the_m.html |archivedate=February 22, 2011 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} The ''Brainiac'' blog earned praise from other media outlets for their timely coverage of events, even as the paper continued to report on simply "suspicious objects".{{cite news|url=http://www.thephoenix.com/article_ektid33334.aspx |title=Mooninite media mash-up |work=[[Boston Phoenix]] |date=February 7, 2007 |accessdate=April 18, 2007 |last=Reilly |first=Adam |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wiHUv6x3?url=http://www.thephoenix.com/article_ektid33334.aspx |archivedate=February 23, 2011 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' editorials derided the reaction of Boston's officials, remarking, "Emergency personnel and anti-terrorism squads shut down more than a dozen highways, transit stations and other locations across the city Wednesday after receiving reports about multiple suspicious devices. The slender, placemat-sized items had dozens of colored lights, exposed wires and circuitry, and were powered by a row of D batteries wrapped in black tape. In other words, they looked like an upscale version of [[Hasbro]]'s Lite-Brite, a toy for artistic grade schoolers."{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/opinion/la-ed-boston03feb03,0,5379741.story?coll=la-opinion-leftrail |title=Full of beans|accessdate=August 24, 2011 |work=Los Angeles Times | date=February 3, 2007}} [[Bruce Schneier]], a computer security expert and writer on contemporary security issues, summed up the incident as a "non-terrorist embarrassment in Boston".[http://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2007/02/nonterrorist_em.html Schneier on Security: Non-Terrorist Embarrassment in Boston] February 1, 2007 {{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/5wiHV4TyF?url=http://www.schneier.com/blog/archives/2007/02/nonterrorist_em.html |date=February 23, 2011 }} ''[[The Boston Herald]]'' stated that part of the reaction in the response could be blamed on two packages that did not blink. According to Boston Police Commissioner [[Edward F. Davis|Ed Davis]], phony pipe bombs were also discovered that day, one inside [[Tufts Medical Center|Tufts-New England Medical Center]] at 1 p.m. A security guard described "an agitated white male" fleeing saying, "God is warning you that today is going to be a sad day." The ''Herald'' went on to characterize the placement of the devices as a "coordinated hoax." Davis also mentioned other incidents of the day that may have influenced the reaction, including a [[Washington Metro|Washington, D.C. metro]] stop being shut down due to a suspected package, and fumes emanating from a package at a post office in New York City, resulting in four people being treated there. "It was almost like we had a kind of [[perfect storm]] of circumstances falling into place," Davis said.{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/bostonherald/access/1209646381.html?dids=1209646381:1209646381&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Feb+2%2C+2007&author=PETER+GELZINIS&pub=Boston+Herald&edition=&startpage=4&desc=PRANKS+A+LOT!+%3B+Phony+threat+escalated+real+danger+in+hoax |title=PRANKS A LOT! ; Phony threat escalated real danger in hoax (Archives) |accessdate=July 24, 2008 |publisher=[[Boston Herald]] |first=Peter |last=Gelzinis |date=February 2, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090314003903/https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/bostonherald/access/1209646381.html?dids=1209646381%3A1209646381&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS%3AFT&date=Feb%2B2%2C%2B2007&author=PETER%2BGELZINIS&pub=Boston%2BHerald&edition=&startpage=4&desc=PRANKS%2BA%2BLOT%21%2B%3B%2BPhony%2Bthreat%2Bescalated%2Breal%2Bdanger%2Bin%2Bhoax |archivedate=March 14, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }} [[File:Hollywood Mooninite.jpg|thumb|left|Err [[advertisement]] located in [[Los Angeles]]]] The advertising magazine ''[[Brandweek]]'' said that the incident, which it labeled a fiasco, would cause marketers to "steer clear of [[Guerrilla marketing|guerrilla]] tactics until the controversy around the ''Aqua Teen Hunger Force'' stunt-turned-bomb-scare in Boston dies down." It further said the incident "will no doubt be followed by a reassessment of the potential price of what used to be known as a low-cost method to generate buzz."{{cite news |url=http://www.brandweek.com/bw/news/recent_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003541692|title=Guerrilla Marketing Arena Soiled By 'Aqua Teen' Fiasco|accessdate=August 24, 2011 |publisher=Brandweek | date=February 5, 2007|archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20070515064238/http://www.brandweek.com/bw/news/recent_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1003541692 |archivedate=May 15, 2007 |deadurl=yes}} According to [[Fox News]], fans of ''Aqua Teen Hunger Force'' mocked Boston officials during the press conference of Berdovsky and Stevens, calling the arrests an overreaction, while holding signs supporting the actions of the two. These signs had slogans such as "Free Peter" and "1-31-07 Never Forget," satirizing Mayor [[Thomas Menino|Tom Menino]]'s mentions of [[September 11 attacks|9/11]].[http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,249241,00.html Suspects Refuse to Answer Questions on Botched 'Aqua Teen' Marketing Scheme] February 2, 2007 {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/5wiHVifAs?url=http://www.foxnews.com/story/0,2933,249241,00.html |date=February 23, 2011 }} Other local Boston residents were quoted by local papers. "We all thought it was pretty funny," said one student. "The majority of us recognize the difference between a bomb and a Lite-Brite," said another.[http://www.metrowestdailynews.com/homepage/8998960763112521727 Blown out of proportion] Feb 2, 2007 {{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/5wiHWPfLh?url=http://www.metrowestdailynews.com/homepage/8998960763112521727 |date=February 23, 2011 }} One resident said that the police response was "silly and insane," and that "we're the laughingstock."[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/16931200/ Many young Bostonians think city overreacted: ‘We’re the laughingstock,’ resident says after cartoon signs prompt scare] Feb 1, 2007 {{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/5wiHX3PVq?url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/16931200/ |date=February 23, 2011 }} ''[[Something Positive]]'', a [[webcomic]] written and drawn by [[Waltham, Massachusetts|Waltham]] resident [[R. K. Milholland]], also weighed in on the issue.{{cite web|url=http://somethingpositive.net/sp02012007.shtml |title=''Something Positive'' for February 1, 2007 |accessdate=February 3, 2007 |last=Milholland |first=R. K. |authorlink=R. K. Milholland |date=February 1, 2007 |work=[[Something Positive]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wiHXQwZu?url=http://somethingpositive.net/sp02012007.shtml |archivedate=February 23, 2011 |dead-url=no |df=mdy }} Bloggers on a Boston [[LiveJournal]] community commented on channel 4 footage of the first device being exploded and clearly identified it as a "Mooninite," reacting in disbelief.{{cite web|url=http://community.livejournal.com/b0st0n/4864959.html |title=MBTA Blows Up Mooninite |accessdate=February 6, 2007 |date=January 31, 2007 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wiHXi4cR?url=http://community.livejournal.com/b0st0n/4864959.html |archivedate=February 23, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }} Karl Carter of Atlanta-based Guerrilla Tactics Media said fans of the show ''Aqua Teen Hunger Force'' would recognize the character and think it was funny, but other people who saw the signs wouldn't get the joke. "This is probably better set up for nightclubs and other sorts of scenarios where the people that are receiving the message, one, would know what it's about, but also two, wouldn't be frightened," he said. "You know, if you put these in certain environments, like public spaces in this post-9/11 sensitivity, then of course you're going to wind up in trouble." ''[[Make (magazine)|Make]]'' magazine editor Phillip Torrone said the advertisers should have used better judgment, but called the Mooninite board a "neat electronic project."[http://edition.cnn.com/2007/US/02/02/buzz.marketing/ Boston stunt creates PR buzz saw instead of buzz] February 5, 2007 {{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/5wiHb5oBc?url=http://edition.cnn.com/2007/US/02/02/buzz.marketing/ |date=February 23, 2011 }} As reported by ''[[Boing Boing]]'', the media and the State of Massachusetts insisted on maintaining the use of the words "bomb hoax" when describing the event, despite Turner Broadcasting Systems' firm contentions that the devices were not intended to resemble bombs and the company had no intent to arouse suspicion or panic in approving the advertising campaign.[http://boingboing.net/2007/02/02/state_of_massachuset.html State of Massachusetts insists on calling ATHF ads "hoax devices"] February 2, 2007 {{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/5wiHbc4GN?url=http://boingboing.net/2007/02/02/state_of_massachuset.html |date=February 23, 2011 }} The next day, Bax and O'Brien on the Western Massachusetts radio station [[WAQY]] weighed in, with John O'Brien saying, "and they [the devices] were also placed in Boston over two weeks ago. I don't think the terrorism officials in Boston are very observant ... Good thing September 11 didn't happen here. We wouldn't have found it until September 20." On February 27, 2007, just a month after the incident, the Boston police bomb squad responded and detonated another object that they believed to be a bomb, which turned out to be a city-owned [[traffic counter]].{{cite web|url=http://wbztv.com/local/local_story_059122735.html|title=Police Blow Up Suspicious Device In Boston|publisher=[[WBZ-TV]]|date=February 28, 2007|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080704223643/http://wbztv.com/local/local_story_059122735.html |archivedate = July 4, 2008|deadurl=yes}}{{cite web|url=http://www.boingboing.net/2007/02/28/boston_police_blow_u.html |title=Boston police blow up traffic counter chained to lightpost |date=February 28, 2007 |publisher=[[Boing Boing]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wiHjMWdJ?url=http://www.boingboing.net/2007/02/28/boston_police_blow_u.html |archivedate=February 23, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }} In the months following the scare, stickers reading, "Don't Panic! This is NOT A BOMB. Do not be afraid. Do not call the police. Stop letting the terrorists win," began to appear on Boston parking meters, ATMs, and other objects in public.{{cite web |last=Begbie |first=Rod |url=https://flickr.com/photos/groovymother/sets/72157594564032667/ |title=This is NOT A BOMB |accessdate=September 27, 2007 |publisher=[[Flickr]] |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wiHqP0EC?url=http://flickr.com/photos/groovymother/sets/72157594564032667/ |archivedate=February 23, 2011 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }}{{cite web |last=Doctorow |first=Cory |url=http://www.boingboing.net/2007/02/01/stickers-this-is-eng.html |title=Stickers: This is engineering, not bomb-making |publisher=[[Boing Boing]] |date=February 1, 2007 |accessdate=September 27, 2007 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wiHqWRTc?url=http://www.boingboing.net/2007/02/01/stickers-this-is-eng.html |archivedate=February 23, 2011 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} On March 18, 2007, at the annual [[St. Patrick's Day]] Breakfast in [[South Boston]], jokes were made about the incident by Massachusetts politicians. Tom Menino said it was a good way to obtain a local aid package for the city (referring to the $1 million in "good faith money for homeland security" that Cartoon Network paid the city of Boston to avoid a lawsuit). Congressman [[Stephen Lynch (politician)|Stephen Lynch]] joked that the Mooninites were part of a sleeper cell that also included [[SpongeBob SquarePants (character)|SpongeBob SquarePants]] and [[Scrappy-Doo]]. State Treasurer [[Timothy P. Cahill]] held up a picture of a Mooninite with [[Mitt Romney]]'s face on it, saying "We had to blur out his real feelings about Massachusetts."live CW56 broadcast of the St. Patrick's Day Breakfast, March 18, 2007 === Aftermath === [[File:MARTA ATHF.jpg|thumb|right|''Aqua Teen Hunger Force'' promotional devices were displayed in 10 different cities. This is one of them, identified at the entrance to [[Peachtree Center (MARTA station)|Peachtree Center]] [[Metropolitan Atlanta Rapid Transit Authority|MARTA]] station in [[Atlanta, Georgia]].]] On February 5, 2007 state and local agencies came to an agreement with both Turner Broadcasting and Interference, Inc., to pay for costs incurred in the incident. As part of the settlement, which resolves any potential civil or criminal claims against the companies, Turner and Interference agreed to pay $2 million: $1 million to go to the Boston Police Department and $1 million to the [[Department of Homeland Security]]. This was in addition to the companies' apologies, which local authorities deemed too little as announced by [[Dan Conley]], [[district attorney]] for [[Suffolk County, Massachusetts]], in a speech on [[NECN]], saying the people who are responsible for this "[[Recklessness (law)|reckless]] stunt", are [[liable]] for the havoc it caused to both the city and the region. On February 9, 2007, the week after this occurred, Cartoon Network's general manager and executive vice president, [[Jim Samples]], resigned "in recognition of the gravity of the situation that occurred under my watch", and with the "hope that my decision allows us to put this chapter behind us and get back to our mission of delivering unrivaled original animated entertainment for consumers of all ages".{{cite news | first=Harry R. | last=Weber | title=Cartoon Network Head Resigns After Scare | date=February 10, 2007 | url =http://abcnews.go.com/Business/wireStory?id=2863647 | work =ABC News|archivedate =April 3, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070403040220/http://abcnews.go.com/Business/wireStory?id=2863647 | accessdate =August 24, 2011|deadurl=yes}} Following Samples's resignation, Stuart Snyder was named his successor.{{cite web|url=http://www.broadcastingcable.com/article/110859-Stuart_Snyder_The_Perfect_Combination.php|title=Stuart Snyder: The Perfect Combination|first=Allison|last=Romano|date=October 21, 2007|publisher=Broadcasting & Cable|accessdate=2010-08-13}} In total, ten cities were involved in the marketing campaign, which began two to three weeks before the incident in Boston. The [[New York City Police Department|NYPD]] contacted Interference, Inc., to request a list of 41 locations where the devices were installed.{{cite news|first=Nathal |last=Toosi |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/front/story/493858p-415985c.html |title=Boston publicity stunt sets off activity in New York |accessdate=February 3, 2007 |date=February 1, 2007 |agency=Associated Press |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wiHrtrxS?url=http://www.nydailynews.com/front/story/493858p-415985c.html |archivedate=February 23, 2011 |work=Daily News |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }} Officers were able to locate and remove only two devices, both located near 33rd Street and [[West Side Highway]] at the [[High Line]] overpass. The NYPD did not receive any complaints about the devices, according to police spokesman Paul Brown. At 9:30 p.m. on the evening of January 31, the [[Chicago Police Department]] received a list of installation locations from Interference, Inc.{{cite news | first = Emma Graves | last = Fitzsimmons | title = Cops not laughing at signs | work = Chicago Tribune | publisher = Tribune Company | date = February 2, 2007 }} Police recovered and disposed of 20 of the 35 devices. Police Superintendent Philip Cline admonished those responsible for the campaign, stating, "one of the devices could have easily been mistaken for a bomb and set off enough panic to alarm the entire city." Cline went on to say that, on February 1, he asked Turner Broadcasting to reimburse the city for funds spent on locating and disposing of the devices. Two men were briefly held in connection to the incident. Fewer than twenty devices were found in Seattle and neither the [[Seattle Police Department]] nor the [[King County]] Sheriff's Office received [[9-1-1]] calls regarding them.{{cite news|first=Debera |last=Harrell |title=Cartoon Network publicity stunt sparks panic in Boston – but not here |url=http://www.seattlepi.com/local/302011_devices01.html |work=Seattle Post-Intelligencer |date=February 1, 2007 |accessdate=February 3, 2007 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wiHsAgVL?url=http://www.seattlepi.com/local/302011_devices01.html |archivedate=February 23, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy }} King County Sheriff's spokesman [[John Urquhart (sheriff)|John Urquhart]] stated, "To us, they're so obviously not suspicious ... We don't consider them dangerous. In this day and age, whenever anything remotely suspicious shows up, people get concerned —and that's good. However, people don't need to be concerned about this. These are cartoon characters giving the finger."{{cite news | title='Aqua Teen' appeared in nine cities, only Boston panicked | date=February 2, 2007 | agency=Associated Press | work =azcentral.com }} Interference, Inc., hired two people to distribute twenty devices throughout Philadelphia on January 11.{{cite news | first = Andrew | last = Maykuth | title = Cartoon caper shows up here, but nobody's laughing | work = Philadelphia Inquirer | date = February 2, 2007 }} One of these was Ryan, a 24-year-old from [[Fishtown, Philadelphia|Fishtown]], who claimed that he was promised $300 for installing the devices, only 18 of which were actually functional. Following the scare in Boston, the [[Philadelphia Police Department]] recovered three of the 18 devices. Joe Grace, spokesman for Philadelphia Mayor [[John F. Street]], was quoted as saying, "We think it was a stupid, regrettable, irresponsible stunt by Turner. We do not take kindly to it." A cease-and-desist letter was sent to Turner, threatening fines for violating zoning codes.{{cite news | agency = Associated Press | title = Police: Phila. had 56 devices like Boston’s panic-causers | work = Philadelphia Inquirer | date = February 1, 2007 }} No devices were retrieved in Los Angeles and Lieutenant Paul Vernon of the [[Los Angeles Police Department]] stated that "no one perceived them as a threat."{{cite news | first = Andrew | last = Blankstein | title = Devices placed in Boston also intended for L.A. | work = LA Times | date = February 1, 2007 }} The many Los Angeles signs were up for over two weeks before the Boston scare without incident. Police Sergeant Brian Schmautz stated that officers in Portland had not been dispatched to remove the devices, and did not plan to unless they were found on municipal property. He added, "At this point, we wouldn't even begin an investigation, because there's no reason to believe a crime has occurred." A device was placed in inside 11th Ave. Liquor on Hawthorne Boulevard in Portland, where it remains. San Francisco Police Sergeant Neville Gittens said that Interference, Inc. was removing them, except for one found by art gallery owner Jamie Alexander, who reportedly "thought it was cool" and had it taken down after it ceased to function.{{cite news |first=Demian |last=Bulwa |title=Calmer reaction in S.F. – 'I thought it was cool' |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2007/02/01/MNGI8NSQTP1.DTL&hw=art+gallery+device&sn=002&sc=749 |work=San Francisco Chronicle |date=February 1, 2007 |accessdate=February 7, 2007 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wiHsgY9d?url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=%2Fc%2Fa%2F2007%2F02%2F01%2FMNGI8NSQTP1.DTL&hw=art+gallery+device&sn=002&sc=749 |archivedate=February 23, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Berdovsky and Stevens were arrested on the day of the incident and charged with placing a hoax device to incite panic, a felony charge that carries a five-year maximum sentence, and one count of disorderly conduct, a misdemeanor. Both pleaded not guilty to the two charges and were later released on a $2,500 cash bond. At their arraignment, Assistant Attorney General John Grossman claimed that the two were trying to "get attention by causing fear and unrest that there was a bomb in that location."{{cite news | url = http://www.cbsnews.com/news/publicity-stunt-suspects-released/ | title = Publicity Stunt Suspects Released | accessdate =December 24, 2014 | last = Serrano | first = Alfonso | date = February 1, 2007 | work = [[CBS News]] | agency=[[CBS News]] / [[Associated Press]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141225044909/http://www.cbsnews.com/news/publicity-stunt-suspects-released/|archivedate=December 25, 2014}} Michael Rich, the lawyer representing both men, disputed Grossman's claim, asserting that even a [[videocassette recorder|VCR]] could be found to fit the description of a bomb-like device. Judge Leary said that it would be necessary for the prosecution to demonstrate an intent on the part of the suspects to cause a panic. The judge continued, "It appears the suspects had no such intent ... but the question should be discussed in a later hearing."{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2007/US/02/01/boston.bombscare/|title=Two plead not guilty to Boston hoax charges|work=[[CNN]]|date=February 2, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070203050621/http://www.cnn.com/2007/US/02/01/boston.bombscare/|archivedate=February 3, 2007}} After making bail, Berdovsky and Stevens appeared for a live press conference. As Rich had advised them not to discuss the case, they spent the entire conference discussing and inviting press questions about hair styles of the 1970s, and ignoring any questions relating to the bomb scare.{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X2fGzmphx4U |title=Boston Bomb Scare Press Conference |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wiHubzuY?url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X2fGzmphx4U |archivedate=February 23, 2011 |dead-url=no |df=mdy }} On March 1, 2007, Senator [[Ted Kennedy|Edward Kennedy]], D-MA, introduced S.735, "The Terrorist Hoax Improvements Act of 2007." It would amend {{quote|the federal criminal code to: (1) extend the prohibition against conveying false information and hoaxes to any federal crime of terrorism; (2) increase maximum prison terms for hoaxes involving a member of the Armed Forces during war; (3) allow a civil remedy for damages resulting from hoaxes perpetrated by an individual who later fails to provide accurate information to investigating authorities about the actual nature of the incident; and (4) extend the prohibition against mailing threatening communications to include corporations or governmental entities (as well as individuals).THOMAS, [http://www.thomas.gov/cgi-bin/query/z?c110:S.735: Terrorist Hoax Improvements Act of 2007], United States Senate, S.735 2007, retrieved May 8, 2007{{cite web|url=http://www.thomas.gov/cgi-bin/query/z?c110:S.735 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wiHui7Ud?url=http://www.thomas.gov/cgi-bin/query/z?c110%3AS.735 |archivedate=February 23, 2011 |df=mdy }}Cheng, Jaqui, [https://arstechnica.com/news.ars/post/20070508-mooninites-meet-the-terrorist-hoax-improvements-act.html Mooninites, meet the Terrorist Hoax Improvements Act] {{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/5wiHv0izT?url=http://arstechnica.com/news.ars/post/20070508-mooninites-meet-the-terrorist-hoax-improvements-act.html |date=2011-02-23 }}, ars technica, May 8, 2007, retrieved May 8, 2007}} The bill never came to a vote.[http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=s110-735 S. 735 [110th]: Terrorist Hoax Improvements Act of 2007 (GovTrack.us)] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/5wiHv84Yi?url=http://www.govtrack.us/congress/bill.xpd?bill=s110-735 |date=February 23, 2011 }} On May 11, 2007, prosecutors decided not to pursue criminal charges against Berdovsky and Stevens, in exchange for community service and a public apology. Attorney General [[Martha Coakley]] cited the difficulty in proving intent to incite panic on the part of the two men and called the deal "an appropriate and fair resolution." Berdovsky and Stevens completed 80 and 60 hours of community service at the Spaulding Rehabilitation Center in Boston, respectively.{{cite news | agency= Associated Press | title=Pair Charged In Marketing Stunt Reach Plea Deal | date=May 11, 2007 | publisher=CBS Broadcasting | url =http://wbztv.com/topstories/Peter.Berdovsky.Sean.2.587093.html | work =WBZTV.com | accessdate =December 19, 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071224143841/http://wbztv.com/topstories/Peter.Berdovsky.Sean.2.587093.html |archivedate = December 24, 2007}} The incident prompted opportunists to acquire the promotional devices from other cities and auction them on [[eBay]], with prices ranging from $500 to over $5,000 USD.{{cite web|url=http://weblog.infoworld.com/techwatch/archives/010023.html |title=Bids for Boston bomb scare promo top $5,000 |accessdate=February 3, 2007 |last=Roberts |first=Paul |date=February 1, 2007 |work=InfoWorld Tech Watch |publisher=[[International Data Group|IDG]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070210222848/http://weblog.infoworld.com/techwatch/archives/010023.html |archivedate=February 10, 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=mdy-all }} Other eBay users created merchandise commemorating the event, including T-shirts, stickers, and custom LED signs.{{cite news | title = Mooninite moneymaker: T-shirts, LED displays hit eBay | last = Marotta | first = Michael | date = February 2, 2007 | work = [[Boston Herald]] | publisher = [[GateHouse Media]]}} An ''Aqua Teen Hunger Force'' episode from [[Aqua Teen Hunger Force (season 5)|season five]] entitled "Boston" was produced as the series creators' response to the bomb scare, but Adult Swim pulled it to avoid further controversy.{{cite news|url=http://www.starpulse.com/news/Dee_Doyle/2008/12/15/starpulse_com_exclusive_interview_with_d |title=Exclusive Interview With Meatwad, Er, Dave Willis, Of 'Aqua Teen Hunger Force' |date=December 15, 2008 |publisher=Starpulse.com |accessdate=December 26, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wiHvLqcL?url=http://www.starpulse.com/news/Dee_Doyle/2008/12/15/starpulse_com_exclusive_interview_with_d |archivedate=February 23, 2011 |deadurl=no |df=mdy }} The episode has never aired, and has never been formally released to the public legally in any format. However, it was illegally leaked online in January 2015.{{cite web|last1=Gonzales|first1=Dave|title=Banned Aqua Teen Hunger Force Boston episode leaks online|url=http://www.geek.com/news/banned-aqua-teen-hunger-force-boston-episode-leaks-online-1620022/|website=Geek.com|publisher=Geek|accessdate=11 May 2015}}{{cite web|last1=Staff|first1=Interrobang|title=Banned Aqua Teen Hunger Force Episode Finally Sees The Light Of Day|url=http://theinterrobang.com/banned-aqua-teen-hunger-force-episode-finally-sees-the-light-of-day/|website=Interrobang.com|publisher=Interrobang|accessdate=11 May 2015}} In addition, Ignignokt appears in the Season 5 DVD sleeve, dressed up as [[Osama Bin Laden]]. ==Historical legacy== Author Gregory Bergman wrote in his 2008 book ''BizzWords'' that the devices in question were "essentially homemade Lite-Brites". Bergman concluded: "That this occurred in Boston, home to Harvard, MIT, and other famous schools of learning, is embarrassing."{{cite book|first=Gregory|last=Bergman|year=2008|title=BizzWords|page=163|isbn= 1598694723|publisher=Adams Media}} [[Computer security]] expert [[Bruce Schneier]] wrote in his 2009 book ''Schneier on Security'' that Boston officials were "ridiculed" for their overreaction to the incident.{{cite book|first=Bruce|last=Schneier|authorlink=Bruce Schneier|title=Schneier on Security|publisher=Wiley Publishing|isbn=978-0470505625|year=2009|chapter=CYA Security}} Schneier wrote, "Almost no one looked beyond the finger pointing and jeering to discuss exactly why the Boston authorities overreacted so badly. They overreacted because the signs were weird." Schneier characterized this as a form of "Cover Your Ass" security. In his 2009 book ''Secret Agents'', historian and communication professor Jeremy Packer discussed a phenomenon in culture called the "panic discourse" and described the incident as a "spectacular instance of this panic". Packer stated the discovery of the lightboards prompted "a city government and media panic".{{cite book|first=Jeremy|last=Packer|pages=144–145, 158|title=Secret Agents|year=2009|isbn=978-0820486697|publisher=Peter Lang Publishing}} ''[[The Boston Phoenix]]'' published an article in 2012 looking back on the incident and interviewed Zebbler for his thoughts on its place in history.{{cite news|work=[[The Boston Phoenix]]|title=Remembering the Great Mooninite Panic of 2007|accessdate=September 20, 2015|date=January 31, 2012|url=http://blog.thephoenix.com/BLOGS/phlog/archive/2012/01/31/five-years-after-the-mooninites-invaded-boston-zebbler-looks-back.aspx|archivedate=March 17, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130317211451/http://blog.thephoenix.com/BLOGS/phlog/archive/2012/01/31/five-years-after-the-mooninites-invaded-boston-zebbler-looks-back.aspx|first=Barry|last=Thompson}} ''The Boston Phoenix'' called the incident the "Great Mooninite Panic of 2007". The publication concluded that the city of Boston was impacted due to the fact that it was "oblivious" to the Mooninite character from [[popular culture]]. Zebbler thought that history would not be likely to repeat itself with a similar event, and surmised that marketing agencies would instead be more apt to first contact law enforcement to get permission for such an event. Six years after the incident, ''[[WGBH (FM)|WGBH News]]'' published an article reflecting on law enforcement reaction to the marketing campaign.{{cite news|url=http://wgbhnews.org/post/mooninite-invasion-boston-6-years-later|accessdate=September 20, 2015|date=January 31, 2013|title=The Mooninite Invasion of Boston, 6 Years Later|work=WGBH News|agency=[[WGBH (FM)|WGBH]]|first=Kinne|last=Chapin|archivedate=July 31, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140731012118/http://wgbhnews.org/post/mooninite-invasion-boston-6-years-later}} WGBH summarized that the overall assessment of the government's response to the incident was critical, observing: "What was the fallout from the scare? Both local and national media outlets derided Boston Law enforcement for failing to recognize a PR stunt gone wrong. Many young Bostonians felt the arrest of Zebbler and Stevens was an overreaction." The article quoted a student who pointed out the vast proportion of individuals were successfully able to determine the difference between a Lite-Brite children's toy and a bomb. WGBH requested a comment in 2013 from Zebbler to reflect back on the incident, and he stated he thought the overreaction by the government was a greater symptom of the American culture during that time period. Zebbler said he would take part in a subsequent [[guerilla marketing]] event if there was a benevolent motivation behind it. The city of Boston hired Zebbler for its 2014 New Year's celebrations to create a light show—and paid him [[United States dollar|US$]]50,000 for his services.{{cite news|url=http://www.metro.us/local/zebbler-mooninite-scare-artist-selected-to-stage-50-000-first-night-centerpiece-metro-us/tmWmkt---8fBbhJad1ps/|accessdate=September 20, 2015|date=November 20, 2013|work=Metro.us|title=Zebbler: Mooninite scare artist selected to stage $50,000 First Night centerpiece|first=Morgan|last=Rousseau|archivedate=September 20, 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150920010858/http://www.metro.us/local/zebbler-mooninite-scare-artist-selected-to-stage-50-000-first-night-centerpiece-metro-us/tmWmkt---8fBbhJad1ps/}} Zebbler said he felt it was an honor to be selected and help bring unity to the city. Zebbler's light show production was the centerpiece of the 2014 Boston First Night event held in [[Copley Square]].{{cite news|first=Tenley|last=Woodman|work=[[Boston Herald]]|title=Artist from 2007 bomb scare headlining First Night|accessdate=September 20, 2015|url=http://www.bostonherald.com/news_opinion/local_coverage/2013/11/artist_from_2007_bomb_scare_headlining_first_night|date=November 20, 2013|archivedate=November 22, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131122164406/http://bostonherald.com/news_opinion/local_coverage/2013/11/artist_from_2007_bomb_scare_headlining_first_night}} When interviewed by the ''[[Boston Herald]]'' about the choice of Zebbler for the 2014 First Night, Boston Mayor [[Thomas M. Menino]] said, "We're a forgiving city."{{cite news|accessdate=September 20, 2015|archivedate=December 24, 2013|url=http://www.bostonherald.com/herald_radio/2013/11/menino_defends_hire_of_bomb_scare_artist_for_first_night|work=[[Boston Herald]]|first=Joe|last=Battenfeld|date=November 20, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131224163144/http://bostonherald.com/herald_radio/2013/11/menino_defends_hire_of_bomb_scare_artist_for_first_night|title=Menino defends hire of bomb scare artist for First Night}} Attorney General [[Martha Coakley]] also felt that paying Zebbler for the light production in 2014 was a good choice. Coakley went on to defend the actions of law enforcement from 2007: "This was several years ago now. Those two young men had been hired by a company to do some guerrilla advertising. At the time, particularly in its proximity to 9/11, I think the City and Boston Police were very concerned. I think we responded appropriately at the time, but I think we also saw the company immediately make compensation to the City of Boston and to the Boston Police for the efforts involved." ==See also== The '''2010 Medicaid fraud''' was a case of [[Medicaid]] [[fraud]] carried out by an Armenian-American organized crime group called the [[Mirzoyan-Terdjanian Organization]].<ref name=CNN> {{cite news | url=http://www.cnn.com/2010/CRIME/10/13/health.care.fraud/ |title=Dozens arrested in health care fraud schemes |publisher=[[CNN]] |author= Terry Frieden |date=October 13, 2010 |accessdate=October 13, 2010}}</ref><ref name=Wall> {{cite news | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB20001424052748703673604575550002841068546 |title=Medicare Scheme Netted $35 Million, Officials Say |publisher=[[Wall Street Journal]] |author= Michael Rothfeld |date=October 14, 2010 |accessdate=October 14, 2010}}</ref> The scam involved a crime syndicate which created 118 fake clinics in 25 states and used stolen medical license numbers of real doctors and matched them to legitimate Medicare patients whose names and billing information were also stolen. The group submitted more than $163 million in claims and received $35 million of that before they were caught. Prosecutors charged 73 individuals in several states with allegations of [[racketeering]] conspiracy, [[bank fraud]], [[money laundering]] and [[identity theft]].
==The crackdown== A scandal surfaced involving a case to defraud the [[Medicaid]] and other healthcare programs such as [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]].<ref name=Herald> {{cite news | url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/breaking-news/dozens-arrested-in-us-medicare-scheme/story-e6frf7jx-1225938441766 |title=Dozens arrested in US Medicare scheme |publisher=Herald Sun |date=October 13, 2010 |accessdate=October 13, 2010}}</ref> With an estimated amount to be stolen totalling $163 million of which $35 million was already acquired by the criminals,<ref name=bbc/> it involved more than 50 ethnic [[Armenians]] living in the [[United States]] who were arrested on October 13, 2010. The operation was run by more than 400 [[FBI]] agents.<ref> {{cite news | url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2010/10/dozens-in-los-angeles-arrested-in-medicare-fraud-crackdown.html |title=Dozens in L.A. arrested in federal Medicare fraud crackdown |publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=October 13, 2010 |accessdate=October 13, 2010}}</ref> In addition to FBI, [[Internal Revenue Service|IRS]] and local enforcement agencies in California, Georgia, New Mexico, New York and Ohio were involved in the probe.<ref> {{cite news | url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-me-healthcare-fraud-raid-20101014,0,7387144.story |title=52 arrested in sweeping Medicare fraud case |publisher=[[Los Angeles Times]] |author=Scott Glover |date=October 14, 2010 |accessdate=October 13, 2010}}</ref> The Justice Department has already indicted 73 individuals in [[New York (state)|New York]] and four other states. 44 defendants were indicted in New York, along with 10 in California, seven in New Mexico, six in Ohio and six in Georgia.<ref name=CNN/> According to the authorities, the Armenian-American organized crime group operated across 25 states.<ref name="NPR"> {{cite news | url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/nation/la-me-healthcare-fraud-raid-20101014,0,7387144.story |title=52 arrested in sweeping Medicare fraud case |publisher=[[NPR]] |author=Ailsa Chang |date=October 14, 2010 |accessdate=October 18, 2010}}</ref><ref> {{cite news | url=http://www.massdevice.com/news/feds-take-down-largest-ever-medicare-fraud-ring |title=Feds take down largest-ever Medicare fraud ring |publisher=Mass Device |date=October 14, 2010 |accessdate=October 18, 2010}}</ref>
==Leadership== According to the authorities, the individuals acted within an [[organized crime]] enterprise run by Armen Kazarian aka PZO a Soviet Union mobster part of the [[Vor v zakone]] who arrived in the US in 1996 and resided in [[Glendale, California]]. The other alleged ringleaders, Davit Mirzoyan, 34, also from Glendale and Robert Terdjanian, 35, from [[Brooklyn]] were also indicted.<ref name=newser>{{cite news|title=Dozens Charged in $163M Medicare Fraud Scheme|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/dozens-charged-in-163m-medicare-fraud-scheme/|accessdate=1 November 2014|agency=CBSNews|publisher=CBSNews.com|date=31 October 2010}}</ref> The authorities said most members of the organization were Armenian nationals or immigrants.<ref name=newser/> The suspects have been allegedly laundering the stolen money.<ref name=RFE> {{cite news| url=http://www.rferl.org/content/US_Charges_44_ArmenianAmericans_In_100_Million_Fraud_Case/2189811.html |title=U.S. Charges 44 Armenian-Americans In $100 Million Fraud Case |publisher=[[RFE/RL]] |date=October 13, 2010 |accessdate=October 13, 2010}}</ref> Prosecutors said that Kazarian travelled to New York to erase a $200,000 debt of one associate to another. When the second associate was unable to pay the fee of $100,000 for that service, his yacht was seized by Kazarian.<ref name=Wall/>
==Charges== According to authorities, the investigation started after they received reports about theft of personal information, including [[Social Security number]]s of 2,900 Medicare patients in upstate New York.<ref name=newser/> The government claimed the group billed Medicare from phantom clinics for unnecessary medical services, or for services which were never performed, by stealing identities of both doctors and patients.<ref name=CNN/><ref name=Herald/> According to officials, about $35 million of the bills claimed by the network was paid out by Medicaid already.<ref name=bbc> {{cite news | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-11539601 |title=Armenians face US health care scam charges |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=October 14, 2010 |accessdate=October 14, 2010}}</ref> A total of 118 medical clinics in 25 states were used to defraud the US health insurance program. One of the fake clinics was run from a small office over [[Coney Island]] auto body shop. Two [[Queens, New York|Queens]] doctors and a worker at the [[NYU Lutheran Medical Center|Lutheran Hospital]] in [[Brooklyn]] were part of the gangster network.<ref> {{cite news | url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/national/2010/10/14/2010-10-14_feds_nab_70_bust_163m_medicare_scam.html |title=Armenian-American gang busted for massive $163 million Medicare scam |publisher=New York Daily News |author=Scott Shifrel |date=October 14, 2010 |accessdate=October 14, 2010}}</ref> The U.S. District Attorney for the Southern District of New York, [[Preet Bharara]], declared that the Mirzoyan–Terdjanian organization, an Armenian-run syndicate in New York and [[Los Angeles]], used threats, intimidation and violence, operating in classic mafia style. Bharara said "This Armenian group allegedly employed a raft of rackets, extortion, credit-card fraud, identity theft, immigration fraud, and even distribution of contraband cigarettes and stolen [[Viagra]]"<ref name=RFE/> The penalties range from 10 years to life in prison. The defendants will be tried in the states where they have been indicted.<ref name=CNN/>
In the state of [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], six people, Arthur Manasarian, 58; Gegham Sargsyan, 56; Khoren Gasparian, 27; Sahak Tumanyan, 43, and his wife, Hasmik Tumanyan, 38; and Toni R. Lowery, 27, five of them being ethnic Armenians were indicted for opening, operating and filing false claims to defraud Medicaid from five fake clinics in [[Brunswick, Georgia|Brunswick]], [[Savannah, Georgia|Savannah]] and [[Macon, Georgia|Macon]] such as "Brunswick Medical Supply Inc". Sargsyan and Gasparian have escaped and are believed to have possibly left the country.<ref> {{cite news | url=http://jacksonville.com/news/georgia/2010-10-14/story/savannah-woman-5-armenians-indicted-medicare-fraud-scheme |title=Savannah woman, 5 Armenians indicted in Medicare fraud scheme |publisher=The Florida Times Union |author=Terry Dickson |date=October 14, 2010 |accessdate=October 18, 2010}}</ref> One of the highest amounts of the stolen taxpayer money is attributed to the state of [[Ohio]], where the criminals of the organization billed the state for $44 million of which $20 million was paid out. All six charged with the crime by Ohio authorities are ethnic Armenians: Karen Chilyan, Eduard Oganesyan and Arus Gyulbudakyan aka Fina Markova the leader of Ohio ring have already been apprehended while Lilit Galstyan, Julieta Ghazaryan and Marine Movsisyan are still at-large.<ref> {{cite news | url=http://spodeklawgroup.com/fbi-armenian-mob-style-crime-ring-steals-millions-in-northeast-ohio-73-indicted-nationwide.pdf |title=FBI: Armenian 'mob style' crime ring steals millions in Northeast Ohio, 73 indicted nationwide |publisher=WEWS |author=Dan Haggerty |date=October 13, 2010 |accessdate=1 November 2014}}</ref>
==Outcome== On July 8, 2011, the leader of the criminal network Armen Kazarian pleaded guilty to racketeering charges. He faced up to 20 years in prison. Sentencing was scheduled for 6 October 2011.<ref>[http://hetq.am/eng/news/2794/ Armen Kazarian "Pzo" Pleads Guilty in Medicare Fraud Case]. ''Hetq.am''. 9 July 2011. Retrieved 18 July 2011.</ref> In February 2013, Kazarian was sentenced to 37 months in prison, to three years of supervised release and was also ordered to pay a $60,000 fine.<ref>[https://archives.fbi.gov/archives/newyork/press-releases/2013/leader-of-armenian-organized-crime-ring-sentenced-in-manhattan-federal-court-to-37-months-in-prison-for-his-role-in-100-million-medicare-fraud-scheme Leader of Armenian Organized Crime Ring Sentenced in Manhattan Federal Court to 37 Months in Prison for His Role in $100 Million Medicare Fraud Scheme]</ref>
